article_metadata.description: Homestretch campaigning intensified over the weekend, as candidates in Tuesday’s special election runoffs made final appeals for votes in two Bexar County legislative districts.  In Tuesday’s runoff to replace him are Democratic former Councilman Diego Bernal and GOP candidate Nunzio Previtera, a member of the State Republican Executive Committee who last week drew the endorsement of Gov. Greg Abbott.  Citing robust mail balloting and early voting, Bexar County election officials said participation in the runoffs appears to higher than in the Jan. 6 special election, whose scheduling after the Christmas holidays was believed to have dampened turnout.  Bernal narrowly missed winning his race outright, capturing 47 percent of the vote to Previtera’s 21 percent, atop a six-candidate field.  Since Jan. 6, the candidates have dueled at a distance, without personal attacks.  When the Senate runoff started, pundits predicted the voting records of Menéndez and Martinez Fischer would seem similar to many voters.
article_metadata.author.name: By John W. Gonzalez, Staff Writer

Citing robust mail balloting and early voting, Bexar County election officials said participation in the runoffs appears to higher than in the Jan. 6 special election, whose scheduling after the Christmas holidays was believed to have dampened turnout.  Bernal narrowly missed winning his race outright, capturing 47 percent of the vote to Previtera’s 21 percent, atop a six-candidate field.  Since Jan. 6, the candidates have dueled at a distance, without personal attacks.  When the Senate runoff started, pundits predicted the voting records of Menéndez and Martinez Fischer would seem similar to many voters.
og.title: Legislative runoffs hit the homestretch

article_metadata.subject: parties and movements,election,upper house,voting,local authority
